meanings.def: to stop feeling angry with somebody who has done something to harm, annoy or upset you; to stop feeling angry with yourself
examples: forgive somebody Can you ever forgive me?
forgive yourself I'd never forgive myself if she heard the truth from someone else.
forgive somebody/yourself for something I'll never forgive her for what she did.
forgive somebody/yourself for doing something She never forgave him for losing her ring.
forgive (something) I can't forgive that type of behaviour.
We all have to learn to forgive.
forgive somebody something She'd forgive him anything.
I couldn't forgive him.
I suspect that Rodney has never quite forgiven either of them.
He fell to his knees and begged God to forgive him.
Donna would not easily forgive Beth's silly attempt to trick her.
An insult like that isn't easy to forgive.

meanings.def: used to say in a polite way that you are sorry if what you are doing or saying seems rude or silly
examples: forgive me Forgive me, but I don't see that any of this concerns me.
forgive me for doing something Forgive me for interrupting, but I really don't agree with that.
forgive my… Forgive my ignorance, but what exactly does the company do?
forgive my doing something (formal) Forgive my interrupting but I really don't agree with that.

meanings.def: to say that somebody does not need to pay back money that they have borrowed
examples: The government has agreed to forgive a large part of the debt.

meanings.def: used to say that it is easy to understand why somebody does or thinks something, although they are wrong
examples: Looking at the crowds out shopping, you could be forgiven for thinking that everyone has plenty of money.

meanings.def: to stop feeling angry with somebody for something they have done to you and to behave as if it had not happened
examples: I know what he did was wrong but don’t you think it’s time to forgive and forget?
He was not the sort of man to forgive and forget.

idioms.idiom: somebody could/might be forgiven for doing something
idioms.def: used to say that it is easy to understand why somebody does or thinks something, although they are wrong
examples: Looking at the crowds out shopping, you could be forgiven for thinking that everyone has plenty of money.

idioms.def: to stop feeling angry with somebody for something they have done to you and to behave as if it had not happened
examples: I know what he did was wrong but don’t you think it’s time to forgive and forget?
He was not the sort of man to forgive and forget.
